quiz.title: Unit 1: Opportunity Cost (Quiz 5)
quiz.subtitle: The Cost of Choices in Economics (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics

questions.question: Opportunity cost is best defined as:
options: The monetary price paid for a good or service
The value of the next best alternative forgone when making a choice
The total cost of all alternatives considered
The difference between price and cost
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the value of the next best alternative that must be given up when making a choice. It represents what you sacrifice, not what you pay.

questions.question: Which statement about opportunity cost is TRUE?
options: Opportunity cost only applies to monetary decisions
Opportunity cost exists even when choices are free
Opportunity cost can be completely eliminated through planning
Opportunity cost is always measurable in dollars
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost exists whenever a choice is made, even for free activities, because time and other resources are limited. Choosing one free activity means giving up another.

questions.question: You have 100 dollars and can either buy a video game or concert tickets. You choose the concert. What is your opportunity cost?
options: The video game you didn't buy
Both the game and the concert
questions.explanation: The opportunity cost is the video game—the next best alternative you gave up. The 100 dollars is the monetary cost, not the opportunity cost.

questions.question: A student can study for economics (expected grade improvement: 10 points) or mathematics (expected grade improvement: 8 points) during a free hour. She chooses economics. What is the opportunity cost?
questions.explanation: The opportunity cost is the 8-point improvement in mathematics that she gave up by choosing to study economics instead.

questions.question: Which scenario has the LOWEST opportunity cost?
options: Choosing between two equally valuable options
Choosing between one highly valuable and one low-value option
questions.explanation: When choosing between one high-value and one low-value option, the opportunity cost (giving up the low-value option) is minimal. The best scenario is when the forgone alternative has little value.

questions.question: A factory can produce either 100 chairs or 50 tables with its resources. If it produces chairs, what is the opportunity cost of ONE chair?
questions.explanation: If 100 chairs cost 50 tables total, then each chair costs $50 \div 100 = 0.5$ tables. The opportunity cost per unit is found by dividing forgone output by chosen output.

questions.question: A business invests 10,000 dollars in new equipment instead of putting it in a savings account earning 5 percent annually. What is the opportunity cost after one year?
questions.explanation: The opportunity cost is the forgone interest: $10000 \times 0.05 = 500$ dollars that could have been earned in the savings account.

questions.question: Implicit costs are best described as:
options: The opportunity costs of using owned resources
questions.explanation: Implicit costs represent the opportunity costs of using resources you already own, such as your own time or property, rather than selling or renting them.

questions.question: An entrepreneur runs her own business and pays herself no salary. Her next best job offer would pay 60,000 dollars annually. What is her implicit cost of entrepreneurship?
questions.explanation: The implicit cost is the 60,000 dollar salary she gives up by working for herself instead of accepting the next best employment opportunity.

questions.question: A country can produce either 1,000 units of food or 500 units of clothing. Currently producing 800 units of food. To produce 100 more units of food, they must give up 50 units of clothing. What is the marginal opportunity cost of food?
options: 0.5 units of clothing per unit of food
2 units of clothing per unit of food
questions.explanation: Marginal opportunity cost equals $50 \div 100 = 0.5$ units of clothing per unit of food at this production level.

questions.question: Sunk costs are:
options: Past costs that should influence future decisions
Past costs that cannot be recovered and should not influence decisions
questions.explanation: Sunk costs are costs already incurred that cannot be recovered. Rational decision-making ignores sunk costs and focuses only on future costs and benefits.

questions.question: You paid 500 dollars for a non-refundable concert ticket but now feel ill. A friend offers 200 dollars for the ticket. The rational decision considers:
options: Only the 200 dollar offer versus staying home sick
All money spent on entertainment this year
questions.explanation: The 500 dollars is a sunk cost. The rational choice compares going sick versus selling for 200 dollars and resting, ignoring the unrecoverable past expense.

questions.question: Increasing opportunity cost means:
options: All costs are rising due to inflation
Producing more of one good requires giving up increasing amounts of another
questions.explanation: Increasing opportunity cost occurs when resources are not perfectly adaptable. Producing more units requires sacrificing increasingly larger amounts of the alternative good.

questions.question: A student spends 4 hours studying economics instead of working at a job paying 15 dollars per hour. The total opportunity cost is:
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost equals $4 \times 15 = 60$ dollars in forgone wages, even though studying itself costs no money.

questions.question: A production possibilities curve (PPC) that is bowed outward (concave) illustrates:
questions.explanation: A bowed-out PPC shows increasing opportunity cost—as you produce more of one good, you must sacrifice increasingly larger amounts of the other good due to resource specialization.

questions.question: Which choice has the HIGHEST opportunity cost for a recent college graduate?
options: Accepting a job paying 45,000 dollars when the next best offers 42,000 dollars and 40,000 dollars
Accepting a job paying 50,000 dollars when the next best offer is 48,000 dollars
Accepting a job paying 55,000 dollars when the next best offer is 35,000 dollars
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the value of the next best alternative forgone. Option B gives up 48,000 dollars (highest forgone amount), making it the highest opportunity cost.

questions.question: A farmer can produce 1,000 kg of wheat or 800 kg of corn on the same land. If wheat sells for 0.50 dollars per kg and corn sells for 0.70 dollars per kg, what is the opportunity cost of producing wheat in monetary terms?
questions.explanation: The opportunity cost is the forgone corn revenue: $800 \times 0.70 = 560$ dollars that could have been earned by producing corn instead.

questions.question: Comparative advantage in production exists when:
options: One producer can make more total output
One producer has lower opportunity cost for a good
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage exists when a producer can produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than others, not necessarily with higher absolute productivity.

questions.question: A software engineer earning 120,000 dollars annually quits to start a company. The business generates 150,000 dollars revenue with 80,000 dollars in explicit costs. What is the economic profit?
questions.explanation: Economic profit equals revenue minus explicit and implicit costs: $150000 - 80000 - 120000 = -50000$ dollars. The implicit cost is the forgone 120,000 dollar salary.

questions.question: Which statement best explains why opportunity cost is central to economics?
options: It reflects that scarcity requires choices, and choices involve trade-offs
It eliminates the need for cost-benefit analysis
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is fundamental because scarcity forces choices. Every choice involves trade-offs—selecting one option means giving up others. This is the essence of economic decision-making.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent work! You've mastered opportunity cost and its applications in decision-making.
scoreMessages.70: Good job! You understand core concepts but review calculations and implicit costs.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on distinguishing opportunity cost from monetary cost and practice calculations.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Review the definition of opportunity cost, sunk costs, and how to calculate trade-offs.
